questions.text: Which viral organism is most commonly associated with myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Coxsackievirus

 

Explanation:

  • Coxsackievirus is a common cause of viral myocarditis, especially in young adults.
  • Other virus includes the Herpes virus and Trichinella Spirali (parasitic).
  • Coxsackievirus is of 2 types: Coxsackie A and Coxsackie B
    • Both are responsible for causing Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in children.
    • Coxsackie A is also associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the vegetation found in Infective Endocarditis compared to other conditions?

choices.text: Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are typically small, friable, sterile and composed of fibrin, and platelets.
Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are large, verrucous, and primarily consist of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms.
Nonbacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (NBTE) commonly presents with small, non-sterile vegetations composed mainly of fibrin and platelets.
Libman-Sacks Endocarditis is characterised by tiny, marantic vegetations consisting of fibrin and micro-organisms.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are large, verrucous, and primarily consist of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms.

Explanation:

Vegetations of Infective endocarditis are very large and bulky, which sometimes fall off and form emboli via blood vessels to different parts of body. They comprises of fibrin and inflammatory cells with microorganisms within.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most likely present in the myocardial biopsy of a Rheumatic Heart disease patient?

choices.text: Areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, Anitschkow cells and fibroblasts in all layers of the heart
Calcific nodules on the valve leaflets
Disruption of the endothelial lining of blood vessels

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, Anitschkow cells and fibroblasts in all layers of the heart

 

Explanation

  • Areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, plump macrophages and fibroblasts in all layers of the heart are the characteristic features of Rheumatic Heart Disease.
  • Aschoff bodies, characterized by areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, plump macrophages (Anitschkow cells), and fibroblasts, are commonly found in all layers of the heart (maximum in myocardium) of patients with Rheumatic Heart Disease.
  • Anitschkow cells: Appearance of nuclei:
    • Caterpillar chromatin pattern: Zig-zag nucleus
    • "Owl eye" appearance: If nucleus is cut from center and is appearing round.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major criterion according to Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Heart Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Fever

Explanation:

  • Jones Criteria:

Major Criteria

Minor Criteria
  • Carditis (Pancarditis) (Option B)
  • Polyarthritis (Option A)
  • Sydenham’s chorea (involuntary movements)
  • Subcutaneous nodules (usually painless) (Option C)
  • Erythema marginatum (skin rash)

Clinical

  • Fever
  • Polyarthralgia
  • Prolonged PR interval

Lab

  • Increased ESR
  • Increased CRP

The presence of either two major criteria or one major criterion plus two minor criteria, along with evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection, supports the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever according to the Jones Criteria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug abuse, presenting with fever, malaise, and a new-onset heart murmur, reports recent injection site infections. On examination, there are multiple healing scars on the upper extremities, and a grade III/VI holosystolic murmur is auscultated at the left sternal border. His temperature is 38.5°C, heart rate is 110 bpm. Which criterion amongst the following is a major criterion for the condition diagnosed?

choices.text: Fever of unknown origin lasting more than 7 days
Predisposing cardiac condition such as a prosthetic heart valve
Positive blood cultures for typical microorganisms persistently isolated from blood cultures

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Positive blood cultures for typical microorganisms persistently isolated from blood cultures

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis in a 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug abuse, presenting with fever, malaise, and a new-onset heart murmur is Infective Endocarditis.
  • The Duke’s Criteria for diagnosing Infective Endocarditis include major criteria such as positive blood cultures for typical microorganisms persistently isolated from blood cultures (e.g., Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus), echocardiographic evidence of endocardial involvement (vegetations or abscesses), and the presence of a new valvular regurgitation.
  • Additionally, minor criteria include fever, predisposing cardiac conditions, vascular phenomena, immunological phenomena, and microbiological evidence not meeting major criteria.

Duke’s Criteria:

Major Criteria

Minor Criteria
Positive blood cultures for typical microorganisms persistently isolated from blood cultures (2 cultures > 12 hrs apart, single positive culture for Coxiella)

Predisposing cardiac conditions such as a prosthetic heart valve (Option C), IV drug abuse (Option B)

Evidence of endocardial involvement on echocardiography (vegetations or abscesses)

Fever (≥38.0°C) (Option A)

New valvular regurgitation

Vascular phenomena (e.g., emboli, Janeway lesions)

 

Immunological phenomena (e.g., glomerulonephritis, Osler's nodes)

 

Microbiological evidence not meeting major criteria (e.g., positive blood culture but not persistently positive)

For diagnosis, either of the following should be present:

  • 2 major criteria OR
  • 1 major criteria and 3 minor criteria OR
  • 5 minor criteria

questions.text: Which of the following genes is most commonly associated with inherited forms of dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) TTN gene

 

Explanation:

  • TTN gene mutation, which is specific to inherited dilated cardiomyopathy is the correct option.
  • TTN gene encodes for titin protein which is the largest protein of human body with over 30000 amino acids.
  • Defect in titin protein can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Microscopically it shows a classical Ninja star nucleus appearance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath following the news of a family member's serious illness. An electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, and cardiac biomarkers are elevated. Coronary angiography reveals no significant coronary artery disease. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Excessive release of catecholamines.

 

Explanation :

  • Excessive release of catecholamines is the most likely underlying mechanism for the development of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy in this patient.
  • Emotional or physical stress, such as the news of a family member's serious illness, can trigger a surge of catecholamines (e.g., adrenaline and noradrenaline).
  • In Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (aka Broken Heart Syndrome), excessive catecholamines act on left ventricle (LV), leading to left ventricle dilatation.
  • Dilated left ventricle cannot contract properly, leading to a hampered blood supply to the body.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterised by transient left ventricular dysfunction, often triggered by emotional or physical stress, presenting with symptoms mimicking acute coronary syndrome but with normal coronary arteries on angiography?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM)

Explanation:

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy also known as BROKEN HEART SYNDROME, is a dilated cardiomyopathy following extreme psychological or emotional stress.
  • This stress leads to excessive release of catecholamines in body.
  • Catecholamines can act on all the chambers of heart but maximum receptors for catecholamines are present in left ventricle.
  • The left ventricle is dilated with apical ballooning resembling a JAPANESE POT named TAKOTSUBO used for catching Octopus.
  • Because LV is dilated and blood is not reaching rest of the body, the patient presents with symptoms resembling acute coronary syndrome such as chest pain.
  • It mimics heart attack or MI but there is no blockage found on coronary angiography as this is not a coronary artery disease.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to his cardiologist with complaints of exertional chest pain and shortness of breath. His family history is significant for the sudden cardiac death of his brother at the age of 28. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur and irregular heart sounds. Which of the following genes is most commonly involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Beta-myosin heavy chain

 

Explanation:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):

  • HCM is an autosomal dominant condition that occurs due to a mutation in the beta-myosin heavy chain.
  • In HCM, hypertrophy can occur in any part of heart but ir occurs maximally in the interventricular septum.
  • Due to hypertrophy of interventricular septum, left ventricle is narrowed and starts looking like a banana-shaped cavity.
    • Left ventricle is responsible for pumping blood to the body which will be affected due to this narrowing.
    • So in conditions like heavy physical activity, where body wants more blood, it can lead to sudden collapse and sometimes death of patient.
  • Under microscopic examination during autopsy, cardiac muscle fibres shows the classical halter-salter appearance (haphazardly arranged cardiac muscle fibres)

Titin (Option A): Titin mutations are seen in dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy collapsed during a football game and was brought dead to the hospital. Suspecting a heart condition, a biopsy was done, which showed asymmetric septal hypertrophy. Which of the following histological findings will not be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Fibrotic narrowing of small intramural arteries

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Ninja star nuclei

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a young male who collapsed and died (sudden cardiac death) with a biopsy showing asymmetric septal hypertrophy is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
  • Histology of HCM includes:
    • Myofibre Hypertrophy (Option A)
    • Myofibre Disarray (Halter-salter appearance) (Option B)
    • Fibrotic narrowing of intramural arteries (Option C).
  • Ninja star nuclei are seen in Dilated Cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause for restrictive cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Alcohol

 

Explanation:

  • Alcohol is not a cause of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Rather, it is a cause of dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy occurs when something gets deposited and causes restrictions in the movement of the heart, mainly diastolic dysfunction/restriction.

 

CAUSES OF RESTRICTIVE CARDIOMYOPATHY
  • Amyloidosis (Pink extracellular amyloids deposition) (Option B)
  • Hemochromatosis (Iron deposition) (Option A)
  • Radiation
  • Scleroderma
  • Tropical endomyocardial fibrosis
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome (Löffler’s endocarditis)
  • Sarcoidosis (Option C)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman from a rural area presents with progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion and bilateral lower limb swelling for the past few months. She reports a history of recurrent fevers and weight loss over the past year. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure, ascites, and hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Echocardiography reveals restrictive filling patterns with apical obliteration and thickened endocardium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Endomyocardial fibrosis

 

Explanation

  • Congestive heart failure (dominant right-sided symptoms) and echo findings are highly suggestive of endomyocardial fibrosis, a form of restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Endomyocardial fibrosis:

  • It is principally a disease of children and young adults in Africa and other tropical areas.
  • It is characterized by fibrosis of the ventricular endocardium and subendocardium that extends from the apex upward, often eventually involving the tricuspid and mitral valves.
  • The fibrous tissue markedly diminishes the volume and compliance of affected chambers, causing a restrictive functional defect.
  • Ventricular mural thrombi sometimes develop, and indeed much of the endocardial fibrosis may result from thrombus organization.
  • Endomyocardial fibrosis is linked to nutritional deficiencies and/or inflammation related to parasitic infections (e.g., hypereosinophilia).

questions.text:
Identify the true statements regarding atrial myxoma.

 

1) It is the most common primary tumor of the heart in adults.

2) It is a malignant neoplasm.

3) It is associated with mutations in the GNAS1 gene.

4) 90% of these tumors arise from ventricles.

5) Histologically, it contains lepidic cells
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 1,3,5.

 

Explanation:

Atrial myxoma:

  • The most Common Benign Tumor Of the Heart (Statement 1)
  • It is a benign tumour.
  • Site- Most Commonly arises from Left Atria.
  • Gross Appearance- Gelatinous
  • It is associated with mutations in the GNAS1 gene. (Statement 3)
    • Also associated with McCune-Albright syndrome and Carney Complex.
  • Histologically- Stellate Or Lepidic Cells Seen (Statement 5)

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with cyanosis and respiratory distress. Physical examination reveals a murmur and a palpable liver edge. Echocardiography demonstrates multiple intracardiac masses located primarily in the ventricular walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Rhabdomyoma

 

Explanation:

RHABDOMYOMA

  • Most common cardiac tumor in adults: Myxoma, occuring more commonly in left atria.
  • Rhabdomyoma is the most common benign tumor in children, which is most commonly found in left ventricle.
  • On histopathology, Myxoma shows Lepidic cells and Rhabdomyoma shows spider cells.
  • Microscopy shows spider cells showing vacuolated cytoplasm comprised of glycogen. These are positive for PAS Stain.
  • Rhabdomyoma is associated with tuberous sclerosis.
    • Tuberous sclerosis is a syndrome which is caused by TSC gene (TSC1 and TSC2 genes).
    • All hamartomas occur under this syndrome, and rhabdomyoma is also considered a hamartoma.

 

The image below shows spider cells.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with palpitations and dizziness during a soccer match. He is diagnosed with ARVC (Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy). Which of the following statements about this condition is true?

Statement 1 - It is an autosomal recessive disorder

Statement 2 - Associated with NAXOS syndrome

Statement 3 - Marked by fatty infiltration and focal fibrosis within the ventricle

Statement 4 - It involves mutation in Plakoglobin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an autosomal dominant disorder. (Statement 1 ruled out)

  • The right ventricular wall is markedly thinned due to myocyte loss, with extensive yellowish fatty infiltration and focal fibrosis (Statement 3).
  • ARVC occurs due to desmosomes mutation.
    • Mutations in genes encoding desmosomal junctional proteins at the intercalated disk (e.g., plakoglobin) (Statement 4)
  • Associated with NAXOS syndrome (Statement 2), it includes:
    • Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC)
    • Woolly hair
    • Palmo-plantar keratoderma (Thick palms and soles due to hyperkeratosis)
    • NAXOS syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder.
